[THE following pages are extraeted from the prefaee to Mersen- ne’s BALmsrmA, published at Paris in 4⁰ in 1644.

They are referred to by Hobbes in the following passage of his Lessons to the Savilian Professors: “ Or if these two,'' (Gas- sendus and Sir Kenelm Digby), “ or any of those I conversed with at Paris, had prevented me in publishing my own doc- trine, yet since it was there known and deolared sor mine by Mersenne in the preface to his BALLISTICA, of which the three first leaves are employed wholly in the setting forth of my opinion coneerning sense and the rest of the saeulties of the soul, they ought not therefore to be said to have found it out before me'’. (See Vol. vii. p. 341).

Hobbes was at Paris at the time Mersenne's book was pub- lished, and the part of the prefaoe to the BALLIs'rmA alluded to, was probably written at his dictation: the ideas and illus- trations, though perhaps not the style, being manifestly his]
